explanation: Explanation
OpenGL (Open Graphics Library) is a cross-platform API for rendering 2D and 3D vector graphics.
The Khronos Group maintains and develops the OpenGL specification.

question_text: What is the latest version of OpenGL?
explanation: OpenGL 4.6 (as of knowledge cutoff, released July 2017).
GLSL (OpenGL Shading Language) is a C-like language used to write shaders for OpenGL.
A vertex shader processes each vertex, performing transformations and passing data to later pipeline stages.
A fragment shader processes each fragment (potential pixel), determining its color and other attributes.
VAO (Vertex Array Object) stores vertex attribute configurations and VBO bindings.
VBO (Vertex Buffer Object) stores vertex data (positions, colors, normals, etc.) in GPU memory.
EBO/IBO (Element Buffer Object/Index Buffer Object) stores indices for indexed drawing to reuse vertices.

question_text: What is a shader program in OpenGL?
explanation: A shader program is a linked collection of shaders (vertex, fragment, etc.) that run on the GPU.
glClearColor sets the color used when clearing the color buffer (background color).
glClear clears specified buffers (color, depth, stencil) to preset values.
glViewport sets the viewport rectangle where rendering will be displayed on the window.
glDrawArrays renders primitives from array data without using indices.
glDrawElements renders primitives using indices from a bound element buffer object.
GL_TRIANGLES draws separate triangles for each set of three vertices.
GL_TRIANGLE_STRIP draws connected triangles sharing vertices for efficiency.
GL_LINES draws separate line segments between pairs of vertices.
GL_POINTS draws individual points at each vertex position.
A vertex attribute is a piece of data (position, color, normal, texture coordinate) associated with each vertex.
glVertexAttribPointer specifies how vertex attribute data is laid out in a VBO.
glEnableVertexAttribArray enables a vertex attribute array for rendering.

question_text: What is a texture in OpenGL?
explanation: A texture is an image applied to geometry to add detail, color, or other surface properties.
glGenTextures generates one or more texture object names (IDs).
glBindTexture binds a texture object to the current texture unit for operations.
glTexImage2D specifies a 2D texture image with format, width, height, and pixel data.
GL_TEXTURE_2D is the texture target for 2D texture operations.
glActiveTexture selects which texture unit subsequent texture operations affect.
A texture unit is a slot where textures are bound for sampling in shaders.

question_text: What is a sampler in GLSL?
explanation: A sampler is a GLSL variable type that represents a texture for sampling in shaders (sampler2D, samplerCube, etc.).
Texture wrapping defines how texture coordinates outside [0,1] range are handled (repeat, mirrored repeat, clamp to edge).
GL_REPEAT causes texture to repeat (tile) when coordinates exceed [0,1] range.
Texture filtering determines how texels are sampled when texture is magnified or minified (nearest, linear, mipmapping).
GL_NEAREST selects the texel nearest to the texture coordinate (pixelated look).
GL_LINEAR performs bilinear interpolation of nearby texels for smoother look.
Mipmaps are pre-calculated, smaller versions of a texture used for distant objects to improve performance and reduce artifacts.
glGenerateMipmap generates mipmaps for the currently bound texture.

question_text: What is a framebuffer in OpenGL?
explanation: A framebuffer is a collection of buffers (color, depth, stencil) that can be rendered to instead of the default window buffers.
FBO (Framebuffer Object) is an OpenGL object that contains a framebuffer for off-screen rendering.
glGenFramebuffers generates one or more framebuffer object names.
glBindFramebuffer binds a framebuffer object for rendering operations.
A renderbuffer is a buffer used as an attachment to a framebuffer for non-texturable formats (depth, stencil).
glFramebufferTexture2D attaches a texture to a framebuffer as a color, depth, or stencil attachment.
Depth testing compares fragment depth values to decide which fragments are visible (closer ones win).
glEnable(GL_DEPTH_TEST) enables depth testing for hidden surface removal.
Blending combines fragment color with existing color in framebuffer based on alpha values for transparency effects.
glEnable(GL_BLEND) enables blending for transparency effects.
glBlendFunc sets the source and destination blending factors for transparency.
Face culling discards front or back facing polygons to improve performance (usually back faces since they're not visible).
glEnable(GL_CULL_FACE) enables face culling to discard certain faces based on winding order.
glCullFace specifies which faces to cull (GL_BACK, GL_FRONT, GL_FRONT_AND_BACK).
glFrontFace defines which winding order (GL_CW or GL_CCW) is considered front-facing.
A transformation matrix is used to transform vertices (translate, rotate, scale) in 3D space.
Model matrix transforms object coordinates from local space to world space.
View matrix transforms world coordinates to camera/view space (camera positioning).
Projection matrix transforms view coordinates to clip space (perspective/orthographic projection).
MVP = Model * View * Projection matrix, combined transformation from local to clip space.
glUniformMatrix4fv sets a 4x4 matrix uniform value in a shader program.

question_text: What is a uniform in GLSL?
explanation: A uniform is a shader variable set from CPU that remains constant across all vertices/fragments in a draw call.

question_text: What is an attribute in GLSL?
explanation: An attribute is a vertex shader input variable that receives per-vertex data from CPU.

question_text: What is a varying in GLSL?
explanation: Varying (out/in variables) pass data from vertex to fragment shader with interpolation across fragments.
glGetUniformLocation retrieves the location of a uniform variable in a shader program.
glUseProgram installs a shader program as part of current rendering state.
glCreateProgram creates an empty shader program object.
glAttachShader attaches a shader object to a program object.
glLinkProgram links a shader program object after shaders are attached.
glCreateShader creates an empty shader object of specified type (GL_VERTEX_SHADER, GL_FRAGMENT_SHADER).
glShaderSource sets the source code for a shader object.
glCompileShader compiles a shader object.
glGetShaderiv retrieves parameter from a shader object (compile status, info log length, etc.).
glGetProgramiv retrieves parameter from a program object (link status, attached shaders, etc.).
glGetShaderInfoLog retrieves the info log from a shader object (compilation errors).
glGetProgramInfoLog retrieves the info log from a program object (linking errors).
GLFW is a library for creating windows, contexts, and handling input for OpenGL applications.
GLEW (OpenGL Extension Wrangler) loads OpenGL extensions and core functions.
glGenBuffers generates one or more buffer object names (VBO, EBO).
glBindBuffer binds a buffer object to a target (GL_ARRAY_BUFFER, GL_ELEMENT_ARRAY_BUFFER).
glBufferData creates and initializes a buffer object's data store.
GL_STATIC_DRAW indicates data will be set once and used many times for drawing.
GL_DYNAMIC_DRAW indicates data will be modified repeatedly and used many times.
glBufferSubData updates a subset of a buffer object's data store.
glDeleteBuffers deletes one or more buffer objects.
glGenVertexArrays generates one or more vertex array object names.
glBindVertexArray binds a vertex array object for vertex attribute configuration.
glDeleteVertexArrays deletes one or more vertex array objects.
glDeleteTextures deletes one or more texture objects.
glDeleteProgram deletes a shader program object.
glDeleteShader deletes a shader object.
glPolygonMode sets polygon rasterization mode (GL_FILL for solid, GL_LINE for wireframe).
glLineWidth sets the width of rasterized lines.
glPointSize sets the diameter of rasterized points.
glDepthFunc sets the comparison function for depth testing (GL_LESS, GL_LEQUAL, etc.).
glDepthMask enables or disables writing to the depth buffer.
glColorMask enables or disables writing to specific color components in the framebuffer.
glStencilFunc sets the function and reference value for stencil testing.
glStencilOp sets the stencil test actions for pass/fail conditions.
glScissor defines a scissor box that limits drawing to a specified rectangle.
glEnable(GL_SCISSOR_TEST) enables the scissor test to clip rendering to the scissor box.
A vertex is a point in 3D space with associated attributes (position, color, normal, texture coordinates).
A fragment is a potential pixel produced by rasterization, with color, depth, and stencil values.
Rasterization converts primitives (triangles, lines) into fragments (pixels) for display.
The graphics pipeline is the sequence of steps OpenGL uses to convert 3D data into 2D pixels on screen.
Double buffering uses two buffers (front and back) to prevent flickering; drawing occurs in back buffer then swaps to front.
glfwSwapBuffers swaps the front and back buffers of the window (GLFW function).
glfwPollEvents processes all pending events (input, window) in GLFW.

question_text: What is a coordinate system in OpenGL?
explanation: OpenGL uses multiple coordinate systems: local, world, view, clip, and screen space for transformations.
NDC are coordinates after perspective division in clip space, ranging from -1 to 1 in all axes.

question_text: What is a quad in OpenGL?
explanation: A quad is a quadrilateral primitive (4 vertices), often represented as two triangles in modern OpenGL.
glFinish blocks until all previously called OpenGL commands are complete.
glFlush forces execution of all previously issued OpenGL commands.

question_text: What is the difference between fixed-function and programmable pipeline?
explanation: Fixed-function pipeline has hardcoded transformations/lighting; programmable pipeline uses shaders for custom vertex/fragment processing.
Immediate mode used functions like glBegin/glEnd for each primitive; deprecated in favor of vertex buffer objects.
Display lists were pre-compiled sequences of OpenGL commands for efficiency; deprecated in modern OpenGL.
GLUT (OpenGL Utility Toolkit) is a legacy windowing library for OpenGL; largely replaced by GLFW.

question_text: What is a context in OpenGL?
explanation: An OpenGL context contains all OpenGL state (shaders, buffers, textures) for rendering.
wglGetProcAddress (Windows) gets pointer to OpenGL extension functions.
glewInit initializes the GLEW library to load OpenGL extensions.
glfwInit initializes the GLFW library for window and context creation.
glfwCreateWindow creates a window and its OpenGL context with GLFW.
glfwMakeContextCurrent makes the OpenGL context of a window current for the calling thread.
glfwWindowShouldClose checks if the window has been requested to close (e.g., clicking X button).
glfwTerminate destroys all remaining windows and releases GLFW resources.
